Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Designing Metal-Exchanged Zeolites with Improved Activity, Selectivity and Stability for Non-Oxidative Methane Upgrade

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512224(Rimer)

The study addresses a critical area of catalysis research - upgrading of methane to higher value products - brought on by the emergence of large quantities of shale gas resources in the United States, along with both commercial and environmental incentives to avoid gas flaring and instead convert the gas to higher value, transportable, fuel and chemical products. Zeolite catalysis represents a potential path to methane upgrading. The study will focus on the design of new zeolite catalysts with improved capability, utilizing both experimental methods and theoretical tools.

The proposed work brings together expertise in zeolite synthesis and characterization, kinetic studies, and density functional theory calculations to design metal-exchanged zeolites with improved product yield and durability for non-oxidative methane upgrading via two processes: non-oxidative coupling and dehydroaromtization. To this end the work will focus on 4 specific aims related to Lewis acidity (associated with different exchanged metals), confinement effects, choice of zeolite framework, and a theory-guided screening protocol for mixed metal zeolites. Given the complexity of the reactions and the reaction environment within the zeolite structures, the linkage between synthesis, characterization and theory is especially needed for significant advances to be made in zeolite-based methane upgrading.

The emergence of large quantities of shale gas has dramatically changed the commercial and environmental landscape for natural gas resources. Much of the remote gas is presently flared with the production of large quantities of carbon dioxide - a major contributor to the greenhouse gas inventory. Direct processes for converting methane to higher value liquid fuel and chemical products are sorely needed. Yet the catalytic challenge is daunting. This proposal will address the current gap in technology and will provide a theoretical basis for future research in the area of zeolite-based methane conversion processes. To this end, it has potential to significantly advance our understanding of both the challenges associated with direct catalytic methane upgrading and the potential utility of zeolite-based catalysis for overcoming those challenges. The PIs will also conduct education and outreach programs to students at all levels to raise awareness of the role of STEM disciplines in addressing energy-related issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused elucidating the performance and reaction mechanism of dehydroaromatization (DHA) of ethylene to aromatics, such as benzene, toluene, and xylenes, using a cascade reaction involving zeolite ZSM-5 catalysts possessing a combination of Brønsted and Lewis acids. The Lewis acid employed in these reactions was Ag+, which was identified to be present as an ion-exchanged species. Interestingly, our findings identified that a small quantity of Ag+ results in marked increases in aromatics selectivity without a significant loss of catalyst activity. Combined experiments and density functional theory (DFT) modeling revealed that the reaction occurs in tandem, with ethylene activation occurring over Brønsted acid sites and cyclization reactions occurring over Lewis acid sites. Studies in this project extended beyond the analysis of Ag+ to include additional Lewis acids (e.g. Ga), using unique synthesis methods to achieve combinations of framework and extra-framework metal species with superior performance in ethylene DHA reactions.

Intellectual Merit: The current knowledge gap in zeolite catalyst structure-performance properties is evident, wherein more fundamental studies are required to provide deeper insight of zeolite reactivity and its fundamental relationship to physicochemical properties, such as confinement, Lewis acidity, and diffusive transport. This project will advance the knowledge and understanding of shape-selective Lewis acid catalysts through a systematic investigation of non-oxidative olefin upgrade pathways for zeolites with varied framework and ion-exchange properties. The obtained mechanistic insight guides the concomitant exploration of complementary design approaches using a combination of experiments and modeling. Key outcomes include the preparation of zeolite catalysts with the basis set of Lewis acids. Concurrently, we have systematically investigated methods of ion exchange and have discovered unique properties of metal-exchanged ZSM-5 to promote ethylene DHA. The results of this project provided strong evidence for a cascade reaction with distinct roles of each acid site.  

Broader Impact: This research plan instituted a transformative approach to zeolite catalyst design, which is capable of circumventing costly, inefficient empirical approaches, and may lead to accelerated zeolite catalyst discoveries. Considering the abundance of ethylene and the importance of aromatics in the petrochemical industry, a large socioeconomic benefit can be derived from our investigations. During this project, the PIs were actively involved in programs at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate levels to promote research and education with an emphasis on increased matriculation and retention of under-represented minority students, at risk students and women in engineering. Findings from this project were be incorporated in graduate level courses at the University of Houston and used to develop a program to attract interest in STEM fields among high school students, focusing on topics such as crystalline materials for alternative energy applications, which are of critical importance for the 21st century. In addition, the PI’s worked with high school students and community outreach (e.g. Houston Earth Day), and incorporated undergraduate research with an emphasis on underrepresented students.
